block.p: Camp David Talks Seen at Crucial Point President Clinton returned to negotiations at Camp David and American officials suggested that the talks, now centered on the future of Jerusalem, could break apart in the next day or solidify into a deal.

Refugees Remain Scattered One million refugees are scattered throughout 40 or more camps in Azerbaijan, where promised oil riches have yet to materialize and per capita income is less than $2,000 a year. The refugees remain victims of a little-noticed war, insufficiently cared for by their government and on the verge of abandonment by international aid organizations.

Ivory Coast Referendum Citizens of the Ivory Coast voted on a new constitution intended to restore civilian rule by laying out the guidelines for elections starting in September. The vote came seven months after a military coup.

Expanding U.N. Refugee Aid The leading United Nations relief official, Carolyn McAskie, said she wanted to look for ways to bring United Nations agencies into a common effort to pay more attention to the plight of victims of war known as ''internally displaced persons'' -- who are not refugees because they have not crossed international borders.

Leaders Promise Debt Relief The leaders of eight industrial nations concluded their annual economic summit meeting in Japan with a broad commitment to help poor countries reduce their debt burden and increase their access to better education, health care and information technology.

German President Has Surgery President Johannes Rau of Germany, left, was in stable condition after undergoing an operation to replace a stomach artery, his office said. Kurt Biedenkopf, the president of the upper house of Parliament, will temporarily handle his duties in the largely ceremonial post.

China Official Visits Pakistan The Chinese foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, during a visit to Pakistan, said that improving relations with India would not come at the expense of China's ties with Pakistan, a longtime ally.

Gun Control Groups Mobilize for Elections The gun control movement has begun its most ambitious campaign to raise money, recruit foot soldiers and build public support for stronger gun laws in preparation for this fall's national elections.

Philadelphia's Two Worlds An 80-year-old neighborhood's collapse into its own unstable landfill is stark evidence that the Philadelphia renaissance that is attracting the Republican conventioneers is a tale of two cities: the glittering downtown of new hotels and trendy restaurants, and frayed working-class neighborhoods like Logan, to the north.

Fighting Drought in Texas Volunteers in Throckmorton, Tex., are working to dig a 21-mile underground pipeline to connect with a water system in nearby Elbert. Officials say Throckmorton's water supply will dry up in 50 to 60 days, if drought-like conditions persist.

Checking Up on Cheney A cardiac surgeon in Houston said that Gov. George W. Bush and his father, former President George Bush, had asked him on Friday to consult by telephone with one of Richard B. Cheney's physicians and help determine if Mr. Cheney ''was up to a strenuous campaign.'' Mr. Cheney, the former defense secretary, emerged in recent days as a leading contender for the No. 2 spot on the Republican ticket.

Energy Secretary Off List Energy Secretary Bill Richardson is no longer on anyone's list of likely Democratic vice-presidential nominees. On the heels of a scandal at Los Alamos, possibly involving espionage, two computer hard drives containing nuclear secrets went missing at Los Alamos, gasoline prices skyrocketed and Congress turned on the former House member with a vengeance. ''I believe in fate,'' he said.

Report Critical of F.B.I. A whistle-blower's manuscript that the government suppressed on security grounds contains little new information, but strongly criticizes the F.B.I. as having mishandled the government's investigation into whether China stole nuclear secrets from the United States.

Census Survey Shows Explosion in Immigration Foreign-born residents now make up 40 percent of New York City's population, an analysis of United States Census Bureau figures shows. The figures are from a survey taken in 1999 by the Census Bureau.

5 Hurt in Queens Shooting A group of men who were turned away from a private party at a Queens restaurant returned and began shooting at people outside, injuring four, the police said. One of the attackers was also injured.

Expanded West Nile Fight Mayor Giuliani announced that the city planned to add helicopters to its arsenal of mosquito-killing tools and would expand its ground-based pesticide campaign to parts of Brooklyn, Staten Island and Queens.

Exam Too Simple, Teachers Say Teachers in New York are complaining that the new, rigorous Regents exams are so easy, and the scoring system so lenient, that even their worst students pass easily. The tests, once reserved for the state's most ambitious students, are being revamped to match new standards, and many teachers had feared the failure rates would soar.

Woods Sets Records at Open Tiger Woods won the British Open, shooting a 269, 19 under par and eight shots ahead of his nearest competitor. He became the youngest golfer to win golf's career grand slam, and only the fifth in history.
Armstrong Wins Tour de France Lance Armstrong, 28, won his second consecutive Tour de France, by 6 minutes 2 seconds.

Australian Wins Women's Open Karrie Webb won the United States Women's Open by five strokes over Cristie Kerr and Meg Mallon. She finished with a six-under-par total of 282 in her fifth victory of 2000.

German-U.S. Phone Deal Germany's largest telephone company, Deutsche Telekom, is expected to announce today that it has agreed to acquire VoiceStream Wireless for $50.7 billion. The agreement represents the first time a company controlled by a foreign government has tried to buy a United States telecommunications company.

Answer to a Wage Question As labor shortages and competition for workers drive up wages in one city, companies have shifted work or have expanded in another location, where the same tasks can be done at lower pay. This movement helps to answer the question of how the nation has managed to achieve its lowest unemployment rate since the 1960's and yet not experience as much upward pressure on wages as it has during past booms.
SBC to Raise Profile on Web SBC Communications plans a series of moves this week to enhance its presence in cyberspace.

Bank Austria to Be Sold HypoVereinsbank, Germany's second-biggest bank, agreed over the weekend to buy Bank Austria for $7.3 billion in stock to expand in Eastern Europe, where economies are growing faster than in Western Europe.
